questions.question_text_1: Total cash inflow in the operating section of the statement of cash flows should include which of the following?
question_texts: Total cash inflow in the operating section of the statement of cash flows should include which of the following?

options.option_text: Cash received from customers at the point of sale
Cash collections from customer accounts receivable
Cash received in advance of revenue recognition (unearned revenue)

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following would not appear in the investing section of the statement of cash flows?
question_texts: Which of the following would not appear in the investing section of the statement of cash flows?

options.option_text: Purchase of land for a new office building
Sale of obsolete equipment used in the factory

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is considered as a financing activity while preparing the statement of cash flows?
question_texts: Which of the following is considered as a financing activity while preparing the statement of cash flows?

questions.question_text_1: ABC Limited, an FMCG company specializing in cosmetics, is currently facing a lawsuit from a consumer demanding INR 5,00,000 for allegedly misleading consumers with misinformation. With the verdict still pending, how should the company reflect this situation in the balance sheet and P&L statement for the quarter in which the lawsuit was filed?
question_texts: ABC Limited, an FMCG company specializing in cosmetics, is currently facing a lawsuit from a consumer demanding INR 5,00,000 for allegedly misleading consumers with misinformation. With the verdict still pending, how should the company reflect this situation in the balance sheet and P&L statement for the quarter in which the lawsuit was filed?

options.option_text: Cash balance would reduce by INR 5,00,000 to account for the law suit.
No impact in balance sheet and P&L statement
Cash balance would reduce by INR 5,00,000 and expenses would increase bythe same amount to account for the law suit.

questions.question_text_1: On January 1, 2017. XYZ Company started the year with a ₹ 400,000 in Retained Earnings, a ₹ 150,000 balance in Common Stock, and a ₹ 300,000 balance in Additional Paid-in Capital. During 2017, the company earned net income of ₹ 40,000, declared a dividend of ₹ 10,000, and issued 900 additional shares of stock (par value of ₹ 1 per share) for ₹ 10,000. What is total stockholders' equity on December 31, 2017?
question_texts: On January 1, 2017. XYZ Company started the year with a ₹ 400,000 in Retained Earnings, a ₹ 150,000 balance in Common Stock, and a ₹ 300,000 balance in Additional Paid-in Capital. During 2017, the company earned net income of ₹ 40,000, declared a dividend of ₹ 10,000, and issued 900 additional shares of stock (par value of ₹ 1 per share) for ₹ 10,000. What is total stockholders' equity on December 31, 2017?

questions.question_text_1: An amount ₹1,00,000 was withdrawn from bank to finance working capital requirement of the business. The transaction will lead to
question_texts: An amount ₹1,00,000 was withdrawn from bank to finance working capital requirement of the business. The transaction will lead to

options.option_text: No effect on the balance sheet total

questions.question_text_1: ABC incorporation rented out an office space for running its business. It entered into an agreement with the owner of the space on 1st January 2025 and agreed to pay a monthly rent of INR 1,00,000, payable on the 1st of every month starting January 1st. How would this transaction be recorded in the balance sheet and P&L statement prepared on 1st January 2025?
question_texts: ABC incorporation rented out an office space for running its business. It entered into an agreement with the owner of the space on 1st January 2025 and agreed to pay a monthly rent of INR 1,00,000, payable on the 1st of every month starting January 1st. How would this transaction be recorded in the balance sheet and P&L statement prepared on 1st January 2025?

options.option_text: No impact on balance sheet and cashflow statement.
Cash balance reduces by INR 1,00,000 and Expenses increases by the sameamount
Cash balance reduces by INR 1,00,000 and create a new line item in assetsection titled “Right to use office space” as INR 1,00,000

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following regarding retained earnings is false?
question_texts: Which of the following regarding retained earnings is false?

options.option_text: Retained earnings is increased by net income and decreased by a net loss
Retained earnings is a component of stockholders' equity on the balance sheet
Retained earnings is reported on the asset side of the balance sheet
Retained earnings represents earnings not distributed to stockholders in theform of dividends

questions.question_text_1: A company purchased machinery worth ₹ 7,50,000 on January 2nd from a vendor. The company paid 50% of the amount in cash, and the remaining 50% was taken on credit from the vendor for 30 days. How many changes must be made to the balance sheet to account for this transaction?

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### 1. **Financial Statements**
   - **Balance Sheet**: Represents the financial position of a company at a specific point in time.
     - **Assets**: Resources owned by the company (e.g., cash, accounts receivable, inventory, property).
     - **Liabilities**: Obligations the company owes (e.g., accounts payable, long-term debt).
     - **Equity**: Residual interest in the assets of the entity after deducting liabilities.
   - **Income Statement (P&L Statement)**: Shows the company's revenues and expenses over a period.
     - **Net Income**: Revenue - Expenses.
   - **Cash Flow Statement**: Shows the inflows and outflows of cash.
     - **Operating Activities**: Cash flows from primary business activities.
     - **Investing Activities**: Cash flows from the acquisition and disposal of long-term assets.
     - **Financing Activities**: Cash flows from issuing or repaying debt and equity.

#### 2. **Cash Flow Statement**
   - **Operating Activities**: Includes cash received from customers, cash paid to suppliers, and other operating expenses.
     - **Cash Inflows**: Cash received from customers, interest and dividends received.
     - **Cash Outflows**: Cash paid to suppliers, employees, and for operating expenses.
   - **Investing Activities**: Includes purchase and sale of long-term assets.
     - **Cash Inflows**: Sale of property, plant, and equipment.
     - **Cash Outflows**: Purchase of property, plant, and equipment.
   - **Financing Activities**: Includes issuance and repayment of debt and equity.
     - **Cash Inflows**: Proceeds from issuance of stock, borrowings.
     - **Cash Outflows**: Dividends paid, repayment of debt.

#### 3. **Retained Earnings**
   - **Definition**: The portion of net income not distributed as dividends.
   - **Equation**:
     \[
     \text{Ending Retained Earnings} = \text{Beginning Retained Earnings} + \text{Net Income} - \text{Dividends}
     \]

#### 4. **Accounting for Transactions**
   - **Purchase of Assets**: Affects both the asset and liability/equity sections of the balance sheet.
   - **Rent Payments**: Recorded as an expense in the income statement and a reduction in cash in the balance sheet.
   - **Dividends and Interest**: Dividends paid are financing activities, while interest paid can be either operating or financing activity depending on the context.

#### 5. **Equity Calculation**
   - **Total Stockholders' Equity**: Sum of common stock, additional paid-in capital, and retained earnings.
   - **Equation**:
     \[
     \text{Total Stockholders' Equity} = \text{Common Stock} + \text{Additional Paid-in Capital} + \text{Retained Earnings}
     \]

#### 6. **Net Income Calculation**
   - **Equation**:
     \[
     \text{Net Income} = \text{Revenue} - \text{Expenses}
     \]
   - **Expenses**: Include cost of goods sold, salaries and wages, rent, utilities, and miscellaneous expenses.

### Knowledge Graph 

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Financial Statements] --> B[Balance Sheet]
    A --> C[Income Statement]
    A --> D[Cash Flow Statement]
    B --> E[Assets]
    B --> F[Liabilities]
    B --> G[Equity]
    D --> H[Operating Activities]
    D --> I[Investing Activities]
    D --> J[Financing Activities]
    H --> K[Cash Inflows]
    H --> L[Cash Outflows]
    I --> M[Purchase of Assets]
    I --> N[Sale of Assets]
    J --> O[Issuance of Stock]
    J --> P[Repayment of Debt]
    J --> Q[Dividends Paid]
    C --> R[Revenue]
    C --> S[Expenses]
    C --> T[Net Income]
```

```mermaid
graph TD;
    U[Retained Earnings] --> V[Beginning Retained Earnings]
    U --> W[Net Income]
    U --> X[Dividends]
    Y[Equity Calculation] --> Z[Common Stock]
    Y --> AA[Additional Paid-in Capital]
    Y --> AB[Retained Earnings]
    AC[Net Income Calculation] --> AD[Revenue]
    AC --> AE[Expenses]
```

This summary and knowledge graph should help you understand the core topics and their relationships for the exam on Financial Forensics.
